item.title: By: Paul B
item.dc:creator: Paul B
item.description: Interesting reflection. I would like to point out that Reagan's <i>"if not us, who?"</i> is a version of the old maxim, <i>"If not us, then who? If not now, then when?"</i> (as referenced in the title of Primo Levi's "Si non ora, quando?"). Which is, itself, a paraphrase of a saying of a much older "great communicator", Rabbi Hillel, in the form <i>"If I am not for myself, who will be for me? And when I am only for myself, what am 'I'? And if not now, when?"</i>. Of course, perhaps that middle question is one Reagan and his neoliberal cronies were less exercised by.
item.content:encoded: Interesting reflection. I would like to point out that Reagan’s “if not us, who?” is a version of the old maxim, “If not us, then who? If not now, then when?” (as referenced in the title of Primo Levi’s “Si non ora, quando?”). Which is, itself, a paraphrase of a saying of a much older “great communicator”, Rabbi Hillel, in the form “If I am not for myself, who will be for me? And when I am only for myself, what am ‘I’? And if not now, when?”. Of course, perhaps that middle question is one Reagan and his neoliberal cronies were less exercised by.
